Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michael Edward Page of Florida International University to conduct an interdisciplinary research project at the intersection of Geosciences, Engineering, and Physical Sciences during the summer of 2013 at Tohoku University in Sendai, Japan. The project title is "High Pressure Synthesis of Phases Appropriate for Earth's Interior." The host scientist is Dr. Eiji Ohtani.

This project aims to expand the available knowledge of geophysical materials appropriate for the core of earth and other terrestrial planets. High pressure combined with high temperature in situ analyses reveals much about mantle materials, including but not limited to compressibility and sound velocity, and will help predict seismic events. This project tests available thermodynamic database predictions over a wide range of compositions, and physical conditions from crust to core. Between thermodynamics databases, not all calorimetric data agree at the physical conditions present in the center of the earth, and this project aims to obtain a match between the calorimetric data sets and experimental values. This research transcends the fields of physics, chemistry, and the geosciences, and has significance towards the understanding of earthquake pressure wave velocities. It will be conducted in the heart of a region, Sendai, still reeling from the threefold effects of natural devastation due to earthquake, tsunami, and nuclear radiation contamination. Thermodynamic relations require that the physical data we obtain through our experiments attest to the relationships that ought to exist between thermochemistry and thermophysics. An internal consistency in such data gives us the confidence to model the planetary interiors and surfaces and lets us compare the profile with data obtained independently through our planetary missions. Because of the broad utilization of thermodynamics by many scientific disciplines, thermodynamic data of many sorts are crucial to scientific progress.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the Fellow plans to participate in the current ongoing project on creating a thermodynamic and geophysical superdatabase on solids and fluids, which can be used with computational methods to help planetary scientists understand the various processes in the earth and terrestrial planets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much (74.3%) of the earth's crust is made of sand, simply silicon (Si) and oxygen (O) in a form most widely called silica. Silica, for being such a simple compound, has about a dozen or more phases it can become. An example of two phases of H2O are water and ice, however most silica phases are solid. A new and interesting silica phase, called seifertite, was discovered in both lunar and maritan meteories and is hypothesized to exist in the lower mantle of the earth. It is named after Friedrich Seifert, a profound German geophysicist. Seifertite is just another form of silica; it is basically a rock, or mineral with the chemical formula SiO2. What determines the type of mineral that forms is the pressure and temperature with depth in the earth. A phase diagram would simply show exactly which pressure and temperature combinations would produce what corresponding mineral. Please see Figure 1 for a phase diagram of silica. You will probably recognize the name "quartz" because it is perhaps the most well-known silica phase.

This research helped to discover new borders (on the silica phase diagram) for several of the phases of silica found in the crust and mantle of the earth. As stated above, seifertite has been discovered in shock veins of both lunar and martian meteorites, but how did it get there? Did the seifertite come from another planet? Did it form upon impact with silica that was already on earth? These are the kinds of questions to which answers were sought. It turns out that on earth, seifertite is such a high pressure mineral that by the time it makes it to the crust it has probably changed to another phase; hence, it is very uncommon on earth's crust. Thus, it is unlikely the seifertite could have come from earth.

Findings of seifertite in foreign meteorites previously and erroneously led scientists to conclude those meteorite impacts had to have been massive catastrophes, because of the extreme conditions (over 1000 kbar) required to form stable seifertite like that in the lower mantle. But they could very well have been wrong. The new information generated has both verified the existence of, and provided evidence for the lowest formation conditions (the shallowest formation depth in earth) of metastable seifertite. Here, "metastable" just means if it cools fast enough, like a quench, it can still form a solid rock we can see and hold. To summarize, a very high-pressure and high-temperature mineral was found in meteorites, and scientists wanted to know if the conditions were really as extreme as predicted by the stable phase of seifertite.

The collected information provides the necessary evidence to conclude that the following scenario is much more likely what occurred to the aforementioned meteorites: dry silica in the form of cristobalite in the meteorites collided with the crust of earth, and upon quickly cooling, formed the unusual mineral seifertite as it "froze" the silicon and oxygen atoms in place. It has revealed an expanded range for formation conditions both on and within the earth than previously hypothesized. Please see Figure 2 for a summary of the experimental conditions examined in this set of experiments, showing the phases developing at each set of conditions, although not in their respective proportions at this time. 

The implications for this information transcend physics, chemistry, and the geosciences, and allow for better models of the interior and other terrestrials planets. With this information, new and better information now exists to classify meteorite impacts as well. This is done by an examination of the minerals in a meteorite, then checking the phase diagram to see what maximum conditions could have existed in the collision.
